Many of the states have launched their own DPEP newsletter. State Level Structures 25. State Implementation Societies (SISs). The DPEP is implemented through a registered SIS in each state. Registered societies are empowered, legal entities registered under the Societies Registration Act of 1860. Such mechanisms have been applied in India to implement time-bound projects for 130 years; they have earlier been used for basic education projects in Bihar (1991), Rajasthan (1992) and Uttar Pradesh (1993). DPEP I has set up societies in all seven states, namely Assam, Haryana, Madhya Pradesh, Maharahstra, Kamataka, Tamil Nadu, and Kerala and they have been implementing the program for 2 years with prompt decision making, smooth fund flow and responsive management. 26. Each SIS is accountable to a General Council chaired by the Chief Minister or Education Minister of the State and an Executive Committee chaired by the Chief Secretary/Education Secretary of the State. Membership in both bodies includes representatives from other State Government departments and the GOI. Eminent educationists and experts in women's education, education for socially disadvantaged groups and disabled children have been included as non official members. 27. SISs have three main advantages over conventional bureaucratic structures. First, as parastatal bodies, they have administrative flexibility combined with public accountability. Second, representation of several Departments of the State Government and the Central Government on the governing bodies of the SISs facilitate planning policy and coordination. Third, financial transactions are efficient and transparent. 28. Registered SISs receive funds from the GOI and State Governments directly and can disburse funds to the operational level of the project through bank
 - 114 - Annex 6 transfers. Under DPEP, these transfers are made to district-level implementing bodies on the basis of the annual work programs and budgets. 29. Regular Executive Committee and General Council meetings are being held to review progress and help implementation of DPEP in the states/districts. The focus of the first few meetings has been on finalisation of rules and regulations, staffing and deputation; designing of intervention strategies; and a review of the status of the program. 30. Though the Bank is extending credit, the GOI has, for the first time, decided to transfer funds to the societies as grant-in-aid and not loans. This demonstrates the significance GOI attaches to DPEP. 31. State-level management structures. According to their memoranda of association, Executive Committees of state societies are authorized to create posts for management of the project. The actual management arrangement in each state and district level varies with local conditions. Management structures proposed for DPEP have many common features, however, including small staffs, linkages with State Departments of Education and other related departments, support for accounting and financial management at the state and district level, and consultancies for accessing expertise in key functional areas. Attachment 6.4 shows a typical state management structure. 32. DPEP SISs employ both staff who are on deputation from other organizations and those who are directly recruited by the Society. The terms and conditions of employment with the SIS are governed by administrative and service regulations which have been framed under the powers provided in the Memorandum of Association and Rules and/or Service Regulations of the registered SIS. District Level Management 33. DPEP is implemented at the district level through units of the SIS, as provided for in the Memoranda of Asociation and Rules of each registered SIS. The Societies' Executive Committees are empowered to specify the composition, functions and powers of the district management structure. While states vary in the specifics of the district level management structures, they share common features (Attachment 6.5). District level bodies interact with the Panchayati Raj structures - the Zilla Parishad (District Board), the village Panchayats - and with Village Education Committees (VEC), which plays a major role in educational management, supervision and monitoring at the village/school level. Staff of the Department of Education posted in the district, including supervisory officials and functional specialists, work closely with the district DPEP units.

All districts have established a district DPEP Committee, headed by the District Collector or Chief Executive Officer of the Zilla Parishad, with representatives from the district education department, non-governmental organizations as well as functional specialists. The district DPEP Committee reviews the progress of DPEP in the district and widens networking with participating agencies. 35. District Task Force. All the districts have established a District Task Force which is the executive body at the district level, and to whom well-defined powers are delegated. Its membership includes district-level officials and representatives of local non governmental organizations and resource institutions. 36. District Project Offices. These have been established in all the districts. In most cases, the district education officer is also the District Primary Education Officer. Day-to-day implementation is overseen by a full-time district project coordinator. A finance/procurement officer, civil works staff and assistant project coordinator for training and gender programs would be in place byAugust 31, 1996. Each district has constituted a planning team. 37. Village Education Committees (VECs). Notifications about formation of VECs have been issued in all the states. The powers and functions of VECs have also been delineated. VECs have been constituted and have undergone orientation training given by the state. The constitution of VECs is more or less similar across states and includes the gaon panchayat president, head teachers, headmasters, NGO representatives, members of panchayat, and representative of parents/guardians of the village. Seats are earmarked for women representatives. 38. The overall linkages within DPEP across various levels and institutions is reflected in Attachment 6.6, where it can be seen at the district level. The implementation of DPEP is carried out in close coordination with the State Department of Education, while at the same time, full-time staff is dedicated to DPEP. Management, Planning and Control 39. The process for management planning and control is summarized in Attachment 6.7. Slightly different procedures are followed for the preparation and appraisal of district and state investment proposals. 40. District Investment Proposals. In accordance with the DPEP Guidelines (Annex 8), district teams develop district action plans with popular participation (Annex 15). TSG has been providing technical assistance in the preparation of district-level annual work programs and budgets (AWPBs). After AWPBs have been prepared, the SIS reviews these plans and determines whether or not revisions are needed. If they are, the AWPBs are sent to the district team(s) for modifications. When the AWPBs have been suitably prepared, they are combined with the state-level AWPB and sent forward to
 - 116 - Annex 6 the DPEP Bureau for review. The DPEP Bureau then assigns the task of formnal appraisal to the appraisal unit of TSG. Based on the recommendation and detailed analysis of TSG, the DPEP Bureau then holds discussions with the SIS. The DPEP Board reviews the package and either approves or sends the proposals back for further revision. If the DPEP Board approves the state package, it authorizes the advancements of funds to the SIS; a sample of district AWPBs would be shared with IDA. 41. State Investment Proposals. State investment proposals for institutional capacity building are prepared in accordance with DPEP Guidelines (Annex 8) and with assistance from national support institutions if needed. State-level AWPBs are submitted to the DPEP Bureau, which assigns the TSG the task of formal appraisal. Again, if revisions are needed, the proposals are remanded to the state and or else, the DPEP Bureau issues approval in conjunction with the entire state package. National investment proposals for institutional capacity and technical assistance to DPEP are developed by national level institutions. National technical assistance program are being implemented by NCERT for curriculum development and in-service teacher training; educational planning and management by NIEPA; appraisal and supervision by LBSNAA; and distance education by the Indhira Gandhi National Open University. All of the above- mentioned technical assistance is carried-out on a project basis under the umbrella contract with EdCIL at the instance of the DPEP Bureau. Flow of Funds 42. DPEP Guidelines require that total project costs be shared between the GOI and the state in the ratio of about 80:15. The GOI share appears in the Annual Plan and Budget of Department of Education (DOE) of the MHRD of the GOI. The state's contribution is provided for in the Annual Plan and Budget of its Education Department. 43. Funds from the GOI to the SISs. Advances from the GOI to the SISs are made twice annually. Grants to SISs are made directly through a check or demand draft by the Pay and Accounts Section of the DOE/GOI, with the funds deposited in a bank account established by the SIS. Reimbursement claims from the multilateral and bilateral agencies are made by DPEP Bureau based on expenditure statements received from the SIS. Because the advances are deposited into the accounts of the SIS, unspent balances at the end of the GOI fiscal year (March 31) do not have to be returned or adjusted against subsequent advances, which is an important advantage of the SIS. In principle, any state or district fully expending the first advance through exceptional implementation could receive a larger second advance. 44. Release of funds to DPEP SISs occurs every six months. The first installment for six months' operating expenditures is made on May 30. It is based on: (a) district and state Annual Work Plans and Budgets (AWPB) prepared and appraised during the preceding December - January; and (b) evidence of appropriate use of previously released funds ("utilization certificates" for years 2-7 of the project). The
 -117 - Annex 6 second installment of six months' operating expenditures is made on January I and is adjusted against actual expenditures from the first advance. This second installment is based on: (a) evidence that the state had made its matching release of funds to the SIS; (b) "utilization certificates"; and (c) the review by the GOI Education Secretary of satisfactory progress in implementation of the approved work plans. The second advance carries the program until the next June 1, overlapping (by two days) the availability of date of the first advance for the subsequent year. 45. Funds from SISs to states/districts for personnel. Appointing authorities (in some cases state governmnents, in other cases district administrations) are reimbursed by the SIS on a quarterly basis for the salaries of teachers in new posts resulting from the construction of DPEP financed schools and classrooms, and as justified by dropout reduction and increased enrollments resulting from DPEP activities. Reimbursement would be on a declining basis as per IDA norms against list providing names of teachers, name of school, date of appointment, and monthly salary. Both state and district bodies are empowered to receive such reimbursements and to credit them on the revenue side of their budgets. 46. Funds from SIS to Districts, Blocks, Villages and Schools. Each society has established rules and regulations for financial flows in its memoranda of association, rules and financial regulations. The rules govern formulation of budget, purchase procedures, delegation of financial powers, investment of funds, maintenance of accounts and audit, and travel and per diem allowance. The Society Executive Committee is empowered to open bank accounts, authorize a Drawing and Disbursing Officer to operate the accounts, and delegate financial functions to state, district, block, village and school levels. The Financial Regulations govern delegation of financial authority for purchasing goods and services, writing checks against society bank accounts, and procedures for releasing funds to district level DPEP offices. 47. Specific mechanisms vary across states. However, DPEP SISs typically have opened a bank account in a nationalized bank in which to deposit all funds received. SISs have also opened bank accounts in one of the nationalized banks at the district level and in banks or post offices at the block and village level. Funds are advanced to districts through crossed Bank Drafts to the district-level bank account; payments to block and village level DPEP cooperating institutions are made by crossed bank drafts. Districts are advanced funds on the basis of annual work plans and budgets as approved by the state DPEP society Executive Committee. Funds are released in installments after ensuring that the first installment released has been utilized satisfactorily. Accountability and Auditing 48. Accountability and auditing are ensured through established state and GOI procedures acceptable to IDA in accordance with the provisions of the Societies

All DPEP SISs have established financial regulations, similar to those established under the Lok Jumbish and Bihar Education Projects, which detail procedures for the purchase of goods and services, including rules for purchase, receipts, custody and accounting procedure for stores. 50. All states have developed general financial rules that establish an overall regulatory framework for the financial management of governmental and quasi-governmental organizations, including DPEP SISs. These rules provide for the purchase and procurement of goods and services, and include tendering procedures for obtaining goods and services of acceptable quality at reasonable rates. For DPEP, procurement, services and financial regulations to be adopted by implementing societies are prepared and provided to IDA for review. In addition, each state government enters into a Project Agreement with IDA. The Memoranda of Association of all DPEP SISs (including the one for the UPBE) provide that the Societies shall: (a) maintain proper accounts and other relevant records; and (b) prepare annual accounts comprising receipts and payments and statement of liabilities as may be prescribed by the Registrar of Societies in that particular state. 51. Audits in the SISs. Internal audit functions have been established in DPEP SISs. The accounts of the society would be audited by an independent Chartered Accountant in accordance with the provisions of the Societies Registration Act 1860. The audited accounts along with a copy of the audit report and society annual report would be furnished to the Executive Committee, which would comment and submit it to the state government. The state government would comment on the audit report received from the DPEP SISs and would submit it to GOI for acceptance. State governments would also, as required, place these documents in the state legislatures. 52. GOI Audits. The accounts of the SISs would be audited by the Comptroller and Auditor General (CAG) of India, under the provisions (duties, powers and conditions of service) of the Comptroller.and Auditor General Act, 1971 as amended. The Act also provides for special audits of societies, which would be undertaken as necessary. In addition, the GOI is required to send the annual report and audited statement of accounts of the project to the Parliament on an annual basis.

 - 126 - Annex 7 INDIA: District Primary Education Project II Management Development Plan Lessons from DPEP I Implementation Process 1. Planning Process. The District Primary Education Program (DPEP) has been developed as an intermediary organisation to appraise, finance and supervise investment proposals proposed and implemented by states, districts and national technical resource institutions. Program structures, procedures and management capacity, had been developed over an 18-month period for DPEP I (Table 7.1). The preparation of the IDA-financed DPEP I credit provided an extended opportunity for learning by doing, enabling national, state and district planning and management teams to implement the activities required to complete a project preparation cycle. Technical support for the process was provided by faculty from the National Institute of Educational Planning and Administration (NIEPA) and the National Council for Educational Research and Training (NCERT), through formal and informal training. 2. With the experience gained in DPEP I, the preparation process for DPEP II states has been streamlined, especially in participative and decentralised planning process and preparation of Annual Work Plans and Budgets (AWPBs). The DPEP Bureau and its Technical Resource Group (TSG) have rendered planning assistance to the three new DPEP II states through a series of missions and workshops and have closely assisted in building state capacity for investment proposals preparations. The training workshops and missions have focused on analysis of key issues and problems, linking strategies with identified problems, analysis of cost effectiveness of alternative solutions, formulating strategies for implementation of key program components (pedagogy improvement; ECE; primary formal and non-formal education; education strategies for girls and SC/ST students; state and district educational management; monitoring and evaluation; and institutional development), and procedures for operationalisation of strategies, phasing, sequencing and costing of activities. As a result, the proposed district and state-level investment proposals are more coherent, holistic and realistic. Schedule of key management development activities is given in Table 7.2. Management Readiness 3. Program implementation for DPEP I started at the time of project negotiations. The DPEP management team had completed an ambitious project studies program, prepared a national program management structure, and appraised proposals for action programs in 42 districts of seven states, as well as national technical assistance programs. All legal actions needed to establish program structures at national, state and district levels had been completed. Procedures for advance of funds and accounting had been established at all levels of the program. A contract with Ed.CIL for technical and management support services for the DPEP Bureau in the Department of Education, to conclude in March 1997, had been approved by IDA on a one-time exceptional basis.
 - 127 - Annex 7 4. The mechanism of establishing autonomous SISs for DPEP has confirmed its advantages over traditional bureaucratic structures (Annex 6). SISs have administrative flexibility and greater public accountability thus facilitating quicker decision making. Representation of key departments of the State and Central Governments results in greater convergence of programs. Financial flows in a society are smoother, quicker and transparent. 5. Key staff had been appointed in the DPEP Bureau for the implementation of DPEP I. This staff has been involved in the appraisal of 12 districts in three new states of DPEP II, and will continue assisting the implementation of DPEP II in 50 to 60 expansion districts in the seven DPEP I states and Uttar Pradesh. 6. The three new DPEP II states have made significant progress in preparing their state and district investment proposals. The SISs have been registered with similar norms, rules and regulations as followed in DPEP I, in all three new states. Key management positions have been filled. All baseline studies and at least two district-social assessment studies per state have been completed, with the remaining ones to be completed by effectiveness. Three state- and 12 district- investment proposals in the three new states, as well as the national distance education component to support the ongoing DPEP in-service teacher training activities, have been appraised by the DPEP Bureau. DOE/GOI has already advanced pre-project funds to the three recently created and registered SISs. The activities financed under the national management support structure of DPEP I have already been extended to cover DPEP II states. 7. AWPBs of states and districts under DPEP II have been prepared, reviewed and appraised during the pre-appraisal and appraisal missions of the DPEP Bureau, which in turn were appraised by IDA missions. Based on the recommendations of the preappraisal and appraisal mnissions, the investment proposals have been further improved with the technical assistance of TSG and the DPEP Bureau. The MIS and PMIS developed for DPEP I would be replicated for DPEP II states. All cost data would be computerised in the database formats already established under DPEP I. Continuing Management Development 8. The DPEP Bureau. The DPEP Bureau has been established to: (i) appraise, evaluate, finance and supervise national, state and district investment proposals; (ii) enter into arrangements for technical assistance for DPEP support; and (iii) service the national management structure. The DPEP Bureau plays a facilitative role in finalising AWPBs and releasing state and district funds. It co-ordinates with SISs, State Governments and GOI for policy matters in project implementation and its participation in the Executive Committee meetings of the SIS facilitates quick decision making. The Bureau also arranges technical support in functional areas, develops and coordinates implementation of national component through national and international assistance. It provides an interface for co-ordination between national institutions and the TSG, and also with external funding agencies.

At present the DPEP Bureau is substantially better staffed compared to when DPEP I was in the planning stage. The TSG functions to support the Bureau and the DPEP Program at large. The role of the TSG is to render technical assistance on the basis of the needs and requirements of the participating states and districts. Recognising the importance of capacity building of the institutions at various levels, the TSG conducts workshops and training programs and undertakes assistance missions to states and districts. It also organises and undertakes supervision and appraisal tasks for the Bureau. The TSG offers a flexible arrangements to hire professional expertise in response to the needs of the program. The TSG extends review, technical advise and documentation support to the Bureau. 11. The present strength of TSG is 22 full-time consultants and 25 support staff distributed over the areas of: supervision; pedagogy and in-service teacher training; procurement and disbursement; MIS and PMIS; planning and management; civil works; appraisal; research and evaluation; media; and educational interventions for girls and SC/ST students. Short-term consultants for specific projects are taken from time-to-time. Consequently the number of staff is not fixed and keeps varying. 12. With the expansion of DPEP, the TSG has been called upon to extend technical assistance in respect of planning and academic resource support to the new states and expansion districts under DPEP II as well. The TSG concept plays an important role addressing core and critical areas for DPEP assistance to states during the implemtation of DPEP II. At negotiations, the GOI provided assurances that it will maintain the TSG in its DOE, with responsibility to assist in the coordination of project implementation, with adequate staff, resources and facilities (paras. 2.48, 2.49 and 5.1(a)).  - 129 - Annex 7 Management of DPEP Expansion 13. Decentralisation of Planning and Management Capacity. With the expansion of DPEP from seven states in 1994 to 13 states by 1995 (seven DPEP I states, three new DPEP II states, Uttar Pradesh, Andhra Pradesh and West Bengal) and the proposed extension to additional districts in a phased manner, the pressure and expectations of the Program from the National Management Structure would continue to increase. There are different levels of expectations with respect to start up and mid-course implementation, as well as demands from particular functional areas. Therefore a system is envisaged whereby the national support would gradually roll away in certain areas after playing its catalytic role and ensuring that capacities have been created and built up at regional, state and other decentralised levels. The DPEP management design has already begun investing in creating institutional capacities through SIEMTs and other such arrangements in the states under DPEP to ensure capacity for planning and management. During appraisal, DOE/GOI agreed to provide a staffing plan to strengthen the TSG to be discussed with the Bank at negotiations. At negotiations, GOI provided assurances that it will progressively transfer responsibility for supervision of the Project from the DPEP Bureau to the SPOs in accordance with a plan satisfactory to IDA (paras. 2.50 and 5.1 (b)). The date at which the Borrower shall provide IDA with evidence of the commencement of such transfer of responsibilities was agreed with GOI during negotiations and set out in a supplemental letter. 14. NIEPA is an apex institution extending support for capacity building in areas of educational planning and management through organisation of training of trainers workshops, developing module for planning and management, developing information systems and documentation. It organises networking workshops with management and social research institutions to enlarge the pool of resource expertise available for DPEP. The Bureau and TSG are pursuing and concretising these linkages to support and strengthen management capacities. Networking with regional level institutions is being pursued at the national level to further enhance decentralised and continuous support in planning and management to the state projects and district implementation. A similar design for capacity building in the areas of Quality Improvement and Research and Evaluation is being followed. 15. Delegation of Appraisal and Supervision Roles. DPEP supervision and appraisal procedures have been consciously modeled on those of the World Bank. There is evidence that the national level has developed capacities to supervise and appraise projects satisfactory to IDA expectations. These capacities have been built over three years of DPEP preparation and implementation by way of joint participation in IDA, EC, ODA and other national appraisal and supervision missions. At present, the Bureau is conducting all appraisals and quarterly supervision missions, of which two are exclusively domestic. A pool of resource persons and experts has been developed across the country through associated institutions. There exists the capacity to transfer and build this expertise at state levels in the SIS as well as other resource institutions. For appraisal of new districts and states coming into DPEP program, the Bureau would in a phased manner, depending on state level capacities, shift the appraisal tasks of new districts to the

 - 139- Annex 8 II. CATEGORIES OF ASSISTANCE I1. DPEP makes annual grants of funds to SISs, which in turn, pass funds to state agencies and to district management teams for the implementation of activities and investments designed to achieve the main purposes of the program at the state and district levels. The broad categories of assistance are: (a) State-level: Building Institutional Capacity. Eligible activities include those which would improve the: (i) efficiency of state textbook and supplementary material preparation, publication and dissemination; (ii) effectiveness of in-service and pre-service primary teacher training and education, and school-based supervision and support: (iii) effectiveness of educational research and evaluation; (iv) capacity of state agencies for research and training in educational planning, management, monitoring and assessment; (v) efficiency of educational statistics systems; (vi) capacity for program management and monitoring; and (vii) strengthening of networked resource institutions. (b) District-level: Implementing Decentralized Primary Education Improvement Programs. Eligible activities include those which would improve: (i) district capacity for program management, supervision, monitoring and evaluation; (ii) the quality of primary formal and non-formal education in order to reduce dropout and increase learning achievement; (iii) access to primary formal and nonformal education; (iv) targeting support for access to and benefit from primary education for girls, and SC and ST students; and (v) experimentation to develop targeted innovative interventions. 2. Application Procedures. States may apply for initial or continuing awards. In summary, the process consists of:
 - 140 - Annex 8 (a) identification of districts according to DPEP criteria; (b) approval of district selections by DPEP; (c) appointment of district planning teams; (d) appointment of state planning teams; (e) preparation of preliminary district investment proposals and cost estimates for eligible activities according to DPEP criteria and guidelines; (f) preliminary appraisal of district proposals by DPEP; (g) preparation of state proposals for capacity building; (h) appraisal by DPEP; and (i) appraisal by donor and funding agencies as appropriate. 5. DPEP Appraisal Procedures. DPEP staff and consultants will provide on-site technical assistance and appraisal for state and district investment proposals. Three missions would be conducted for each state: (a) at the initiation of project preparation; (b) on completion of draft investment proposals; and (c) on completion of revised investment proposals. These missions would be complemented with an appraisal of the DPEP capacity to appraise state and sample district investment proposals (plans) by the donor and funding agencies. 6. DPEP Supervision Procedures. Annex 16 describes in full detail the supervision plan agreed with GOI for DPEP I and II.

 - 145 - Annex 10 INDIA: District Primary Education Project II Institutional Development Context and Objectives 1. The proposed Project would support district-based activities aimed at improving access to quality primary education, reducing dropout and increasing learning achievement. Special attention would be paid to girls, SC and ST students and students with special educational needs. By the end of the Project, schools in the Project districts would be inclusive schools where all children learn and achieve to their potential. Participation of local communities in school management and mobilization of resources would be enhanced to increase stakeholder ownership. 2. To achieve the objectives outlined above the Project will support the development of the capacity of the state, district and sub-district institutions to provide technical support for textbook and supplementary reading material development, improving teaching, evaluation and research, and planning and management in the three new states. This implies strengthening in the expansion states the capacity of the professional institutions (SCERT and SIEMT, Textbook Board), and at the national level ensuring that there is an adequate base of resource institutions to support this process (with support of national capacity building component in DPEP I). Furthermore, the Project is desired to enhance district institutional capacity to plan and manage program delivery, strengthen community participation and awareness, continuous in-service training of teachers backed by on-site supervision and support, learning materials and teaching aids, targeted interventions for girls, SC, ST and students with special education needs. Inputs from line and parallel institutions including NGOs are critical for implementation. Institutional development to perform specified roles in the changing pedagogy and managerial environment would converge on school improvement and effectiveness. A framework for institutional development in the three new states and in expansion states is presented below. Lessons Learned 3. Two institutional development lessons have been learned in the process of implementing DPEP I. First, the establishment of state resource groups on curriculum and learning material, and in-service teacher training is critical to the implementation of
 - 146 - Annex 10 the process of pedagogical renewal time delays. Second, the expedition of DIETs, block resource centers (BRCs) and cluster resource centers (CRCs) need to be operationalized early in the Project as training and on-site support depends on it. Sirnilarly, delay in operationalisation of SIEMT, or the planning and management unit in an existing state, results in lack of mobilization of managerial back-up for integrated school improvement after in-service training. During negotiations, Project states agreed that each Project state shall establish and maintain a state level technical resource group to assist in the development and implementation of programs to improve primary education teaching processes (paras 2.10 and 5.2(c)). The BRCs and CRCs will also be expected to start operating in the first year so that the staff is involved in planning staff and teacher development activities to stimulate ownership and program implementation commitment. Similarly, at least core staff for SIEMT or a unit in an existing institution will be appointed early on so that integrated teacher training and technically improved managerial support will beavailable for school improvement and effectiveness. 4. In DPEP I, the stress on building institutional capacity has been mostly on technical assistance for training. This, however, is not sufficient for effective implementation of a complex program like DPEP. Training needs to be complemented by sustained inputs through a variety of integrated activities such as, supervision and support, supply of supplementary reading material, and teaching aids. Like DPEP I, the three new states would identify resource institutions within or outside their state for specific tasks and carry out systematic assessment of their capacities. Strategies 5. The institutional development strategy would have the following elements: (a) Identifying resource institutions and networking: The resource institutions and NGOs for specific tasks would be identified and their capacities assessed and terms for collaboration or memorandum understanding would be negotiated through a transparent process. Functional networks of institutions, consulting firms and NGOs would be established. (b) Variety of arrangements: Institutional capacity building goes beyond training and workshops. Besides these activities, mentoring, twinning, information exchange and on-site study visit within the state, outside the state in the country and outside the country would be supported to develop institutional capacity. Fellowships and longer training in critical areas would also be supported.
 - 147- Annex 10 (c) Consultancies: Institutional capacity building at the state, district, BRC and CRC levels will require technical resource support to complement the line institutions to implement several activities in the expansion scenario. The necessary technical support consultancies would be supported by the Project. Basic Education Project (UPBEP). Directions for the Project 4. Use of Consultants for Design and Supervision. Experience from UPBEP and DPEP I has indicated that in the preparation of the construction manuals and designs for the classroom and BRC construction the states have continued to promote the "classic" classroom approach commonly associated with Public Works Department (PWD) construction. Designs for SIEMTs, Ashrams, and other unique facilities proposed under the project tend to follow the same pattern. An analysis of these past practices reveal that a change in attitude on the part of the educationalists was needed so that they view themselves as involved owner, rather than a passive recipient of whatever the engineers provide them in the way of facilities. Since PWD offices are generally not accustomed or organized to provide this collaborative type of arrangement, this project will promote the hiring of a design consultants at the state or district levels who would be responsible to the ministry in the preparation of plans and specifications which complement and respond to the education programs espoused by DPEP. The state and district education teams will work with the consultant designers and other "stakeholders" in the process to help them understand the needs and requirements of the program - whether it be a classroom earmarked for multi- grade teaching, an SCERT renovation, or a Block Resource Center. Other "stakeholders" might include the PWD, if they are eventually expected to construct the facility, or occupants
 - 169- Annex 13 of the facility itself, such as a teacher, or a SCERT official. Consultant agreements with design professionals will also be planned at the SPO and TSG levels to strengthen quality control and review roles inherent in those organizations with respect to the oversight of the civil works programs at the state and district levels. 5. A second area identified for strengthening in this project following on the experiences of the earlier DPEP projects is in the arrangements for supervision of the works under construction. Most plans call for inspection by PWD personnel or junior engineers at local Panchyat levels. This is a reasonable procedure, especially if the PWD has been charged with the responsibility to tender and award the construction by contract arrangements. Nevertheless, experience on the previous DPEP projects has shown that supervision by staff engineers alone is often too erratic to insure the necessary quality control. To strengthen the quality control program where existing "organizational" structures are weak or ineffective, states plan to contract for third party supervision by contract arrangement with an architectural or engineering firm. Terms of reference for such contracts would provide for site visits to active construction sites at a frequency of roughly three times per month over a given period of time, say six months. Travel and per diem costs would be included within the contract fees, and the supervision firm would be responsible for providing site visit reports to the State/District project team. Such arrangements are not meant to replace the PWD/Panchayat inspectors, but rather to supplement them. The primary function is to alert the State/District project management team to construction quality issues that need immediate attention. 6. Classroom Construction Innovation Fund. While the construction programs proposed by the states address the physical needs of the program in one sense (i.e., new classrooms will be built), the evidence from UPBEP and DPEP I suggest that little is being done to advance the "state of the art" in classroom construction. Given the present classroom shortage, it is imperative to reduce the unit cost of the buildings. Throughout the country there are many reputable agencies specializing in alternative building technologies and cost effective construction techniques. Accordingly, to assist the states in tapping into the pool of expertise that might be used in advancing the local "state of the art", a new element being introduced to the project is the establishment of a Rs. 50 lakh Classroom Construction Innovation Fund at each of the state level societies in Gujarat, Himachal Pradesh and Orissa. The purpose of the fund will be to provide the resources for a state effort directed toward the research, experimentation and evaluation of alternative, "low cost" techniques for construction of classroom facilities. 7. The Innovation Fund would be utilized in part for a design undertaking though a collaborative effort involving consultant architects, regional polytechnics, educationalists, and state construction agencies. The fund would also finance the actual construction of prototype designs in communities covered by the DPEP II project. Initially, the construction of these prototype classrooms would be a parallel activity to the ongoing construction of more traditional designs during the early stages of the DPEP II implementation period. However, once an evaluation has been made of successful, replicable techniques in the prototype classrooms, it is expected that these alternative methods of construction would be incorporated into the classroom construction program during the remaining project period.

 - 174- Annex 14 INDIA: District Primary Education Project II Economic and Financial Issues 1. This annex has six sections. The first presents evidence from studies of the economic and social outcomes of primary education in India in general and discusses some of the projected outcomes of the project. The second summarises the results of recent economic and sector work (ESW) on the determinants of learning achievement and the most cost effective interventions. The four remaining sections concentrate on financial issues of the project. They record the educational expenditures of IDA-supported DPEP I states since the beginning of that project, describe expenditure patterns in the three new DPEP states, and consider the issues of additionality and financial sustainability for the new and expansion states in DPEP II. The results inform the final section which discusses the implications of the analysis for the appraisal of expansion states and for project supervision. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL IMPACT 2. The economic impact of primary schooling in India has been measured several times through rate of return studies. These have been very geographically limited and the most recent comprehensive analysis used data for 1978. Adjusting the basic set of estimates for wastage gave social rates of return of 13 and 15 percent for primary and upper primary schooling respectively (Tilak 1987). Foster and Rosenzweig (1994a) recently analyzed data sets over the period 1968 to 1982 to investigate the effects of education on the utilization of technical change, and the outcomes, in agriculture. They concluded that for every one rupee increase in profit due to the effects of exogenous technical change, those households with primary schooling experienced an additional 1.38 rupees and that schooling appeared to have a substantially more important effect in enhancing farmer productivity from high yielding varieties of grain than did the extension services. A second analysis of the data sets concluded that information externalities are important in the early stages of the adoption of new technologies. Farmers with no or little schooling benefitted from their more schooled neighbors who were the first to adopt the new seeds. 3. The level of schooling has influenced poverty reduction as well as economic growth. Datt and Ravallion (1995) investigated the uneveness in changes in rural living standards and levels of poverty across Indian states between 1957 and 1991. Living standards were raised by higher agricultural yields, lower inflation and higher state spending on development programs. Such factors, however, provided only a partial explanation of relative success and failure between states. States with better infrastructure in general and higher levels of literacy in particular at the beginning of the period had significantly higher long-term rates of both consumption growth and poverty reduction. 4. Finally, an aggregate production function study to assess the impact of primary schooling on economic growth in India was commissioned as part of recent ESW. This was
 - 175 - Annex 14 based on a simplified version of the Bank study of successful Southeast Asian economies but used data for individual states. An attempt was made to disaggregate the sources of growth over the period 1961 to 1981. For the first decade the results were largely insignificant. For the later period the results indicated a substantial effect of education, and primary education in particular, on economic growth.. Now that the approach has been introduced to Indian scholars, it is hoped that the study will be updated and refined once the labor force data from the 1991 Census are published. 5. A second study commissioned for the ESW attempted to estimate the coverage, efficiency and effectiveness of school incentive programs in two states. Across the country there are very many incentive programs, mainly for scheduled caste and scheduled tribe children, and for poor girls. The most common programs are free textbooks and uniforms. Some states provide writing materials, sandals and attendance allowances. Noon day meal programs which were operated in some states (notably in Tamil Nadu and Orissa) have recently been substituted by a comprehensive central government program. After teachers salaries, the cost of incentive programs is the major component of the unit cost of primary education. Previous evaluations of incentive programs have only focused on the impact of noon day meal schemes on enrollment and retention. The results have not been conclusive. The study for the ESW concentrated on Haryana and Maharashtra. In these two states, expenditure on incentives was twice that on all other school inputs combined (apart from teacher salaries). Overall, the results indicated that while the incentives are of great importance for the very poor, parents in general are more influenced by the perceived utility and quality of schooling. While not influencing the state governments' own expenditures on incentives, the DPEP Guidelines omit these programs from the list of eligible items. 6. Evidence of the social impact of primary schooling has been greatly strengthened by the recent publication of the National Family Health Surveys for each major state based on data collected during 1992-93. Data on fertility, child health and nutritional status by mother's eduation for each of the three new DPEP II states is presented in Table 1. 7. The total fertility rate and the ideal number of children differ significantly by level of mother's education in each state. The impact of literacy and some elementary education is particularly evident. Given that reductions in fertility reflect desired changes, private benefits accrue both to the couples and their children in the sense that fewer children tend to receive higher investments in schooling and parental time. Reduced fertility rates, however, are also generally regarded as being economically beneficial to society as a whole in countries such as India with high rates of population growth. 8. A second area where schooling has been shown to have strong effects on behavior in the Surveys is health, particularly child health. Within each of the states there is a very clear pattern of lower infant (and child) mortality rates for mothers with increasingly higher levels of education. In Gujarat in particular, infant mortality rates decrease very substantially for children of those mothers with some elementary schooling. Child mortality rates decrease by between a quarter and a third with this level of schooling. Mortality, and morbidity, are likely to be influenced by the prevalence of immunization. The percentages of
 - 176 - Annex 14 children below the age of 23 months who had received the full Extended Programme of Immunization by level of their mother's schooling are shown in Table 1. Some elementary schooling is strongly associated with an increase in the full set of vaccinations (and with the reductions in the percentage of children with no vaccinations). Reductions in infant and child mortality and morbidity reduce suffering and increase the physical strength of surviving children. They also reduce the time that women are removed from the labor market for compensatory additional childbirth and treating child illness. In turn this increases female labor force participation.  - 177 - Annex 14 9. Mother's schooling also influences children's nutritional status. The Surveys recorded levels of severely undernourished children by mother's educational level. Reductions are quite strongly related to literacy and some elementary schooling. There is substantial cross- country evidence that healthy and well-nourished children utilize educational inputs more effectively. 10. The data presented above for the new project states of Gujarat, Himachal Pradesh and Orissa demonstrate the very strong relationships between the level of schooling, and of mothers in particular, and the levels of fertility, child health and nutritional status of families. Comparisons across other Indian states which are at very different stages of primary school development suggest a second type of impact. For each level of education, the effects on the individual appear to be greater the broader is the coverage of that level of education across the community. This conclusion parallels the studies of the impact of schooling on agricultural innovation which demonstrated the external benefits resulting from a sufficiently large body of literate farmers. DPEP districts are, by definition, educationally backward. The relationships described above suggest that significant returns can be expected from the universalization of schooling in general and the proposed project in particular. 11. In addition to an increase in access to primary schooling, the project aims to substantially increase quality. One consequence would be an increased level of internal efficiency in the system. Across India, both dropout and repetition rates are high. Roughly, a provision of a total of 8.5 years of schooling is required to produce one graduate of the five year primary school cycle. Alternatively expressed, up to 70 percent more resources are being used than would be necessary in a situation of no dropout or repetition. On the assumption that increases in the quality of inputs will reduce repetition and dropout levels by half, a total of 6.3 years would be required - around 25 percent above those in a perfectly operating system. Rough estimations suggest that the quality-enhancing interventions associated with DPEP will add around one sixth to the unit cost of primary schooling. If these halve the repetition and dropout rates, they would reduce costs per graduate by one quarter. This is in addition to the benefits directly derived from increases in learning achievement. INTERVENTIONS FOR INCREASED LEARNING ACHIEVEMENT 12. Over the past two years, analyses of the determinants of learning in primary schools and the costs of specific interventions have been undertaken based on extensive survey work in 39 low literacy districts in eight states. Pupil achievement surveys include data collection on pupil, family, community and school characteristics. Costs of potential interventions are being taken from the results of detailed field studies of the unit cost of primary schooling in two states, as well as from the surveys. This major program of action research into learning achievements and its determinants is being undertaken by each district and state applying for inclusion in the DPEP. The current analytical work is using data collected in 1993. Capacity to utilize the analytical framework (HLM analysis) has been developed through technical assistance. Members of the DPEP Bureau and the Technical Support Group have been integrally involved in the design and the analytical framework developed for the baseline achievement studies and India's major educational research and training institution (NCERT)
 - 178 - Annex 14 has been the nodal agency. These members are also actively involved in introducing the new DPEP states to the process of plan formulation and in monitoring the activities of the DPEP I states. This ambitious program to measure and analyze the levels and determinants of learning achievement is an inbuilt feature of the DPEP and is meant to continuously feed into the national debate on school effectiveness and the district proposals and annual work programs. 13. The second stage in the process will be to apply costs to those factors which influence learning and are susceptible to policy intervention. This is being undertaken, currently within the Bank, largely for illustrative purposes.  - 191 - Annex 15 INDIA: District Primary Education Project II Social Assessment and Participation BACKGROUND 1. Historically education has been recognized as the key to development. India, in its plan to provide universal education by the year 2000, has demonstrated a clear understanding of this principle. The District Primary Education Program (DPEP) has been designed to help districts develop a comprehensive plan to meet the education needs of children between 6 and 11 years old. DPEP, in setting criteria that selected districts have a female literacy of less than 39.2 percent, places special emphasis on those groups who have traditionally been isolated from the educational system: the scheduled tribes (ST), scheduled castes (SC) and girls. The 42 districts included in phase one of the DPEP program have provided experience which will be of valuable assistance in meeting the challenges of the additional 60 to 70 districts in DPEP 11 (12 in the three new states, and between 50 to 60 in the seven DPEP I states and Uttar Pradesh). Although geographic or demographic data differ, the issues faced by the SC/ST and female population of the DPEP II districts do not significantly differ from those recorded in DPEP 1. 2. This Annex describes the relevant issues faced by girls, SC and ST primary education students concerning their access and retention in the primary school system and the quality of education they receive. Based on the lessons learned during the implementation of DPEP I, the Annex proposes a strategy to address these issues. GENDER ISSUES 3. Access. As can be seen from the table describing the district profiles in the three new states in Annex 9, female enrollment rates are significantly below 50 percent: 6 districts register lower than 45 percent female enrollment. Social, cultural and economic conditions contribute to these low enrollment figures. Parents, many of whom are illiterate themselves, do not see the importance of an education for girls; in fact, it has negative economic and social consequences. An educated girl encounters a more difficult time in finding a suitable marriage partner; Education is perceived as leading to an erosion of traditional values; Limited family resources are reserved for the educational needs of boys as they are seen as a source of support and income for old age; School is perceived to add a financial burden: books, clothes, school fees, etc., making it a hardship for poor families to send their children to school. Girls are required to assist in domestic and agricultural chores and to provide sibling care;
 - 192- Annex 15 * School timings interfere with the work schedule of girls; * Parents are concerned for the security of girls who must walk to remotely located schools; * The lack of female teachers is a motivational and security issue; * Daughters of migrant laborers often settle in locations without schools; and * Schools are not available in all villages. 4. Retention. This same table shows that the average dropout rate of girls, 49 percent, is considerably higher than that of 39 percent for boys. Although much of this can be attributed to the low priority given to girls education, other factors must be considered. * Schools are poorly maintained; * Drinking water and toilet facilities are not available; * Teachers are often absent or not motivated; * Many students are afraid of teachers who are known to punish; * Girls, once reaching puberty are kept at home; * Girls marry at an early age and drop out; *^ Inflexible school calendar timings affects migrant laborers and those faced with seasonal responsibilities, such as harvesting. Increased absenteeism during these periods ultimately leads to a desire to drop out; and * Peer pressure by other dropouts encourages similar behavior. 5. Quality. The average female literacy rate in the 12 districts is 26 percent while males achieve 51, a difference of 25 points. Poor achievement can be attributed to the quality of the curriculum and the skill of the teacher. * The curriculum, which does not include references to traditional female activities , e.g., spinning, weaving, or farming are perceived as irrelevant by parents and students alike; * Incentives such as playgrounds, teaching aids or activities, e.g., sports, music or drama to make school more interesting, are lacking; * Teachers are often not qualified, poorly trained and supervised; * Gender bias is evident in both teaching materials and teaching staff who often see girls as less intelligent; * Remedial help is seldom available; and * Textbooks are unattractive. ST/SC ISSUES 6. India's ST/SC population, along with a history of discrimination, face additional problems of poverty, physical isolation in sparsely populated habitations, and a cultural and language divergence from the mainstream. These factors have kept enrollment, retention and achievement rates low for these groups.
 - 193 - Annex 15 7. Access. A significant portion of the tribal groups in the DPEP II districts inhabit locations with difficult terrains making it problematic for students to reach school and for teachers to commute to their localities: * There are fewer schools in sparsely populated areas; * Schools, even one kilometer away, are often inaccessible due to difficult terrain; * Parents, illiterate themselves, do not encourage school enrollment; * Teachers, particularly female teachers, are unwilling to serve in hardship areas, and accommodations are not available; * Children have domestic and sibling responsibility which interfere with school timings; * Students, particularly girls in tribal areas, require an escort to take them to distant schools; and * Families of educated tribal girls are often subject to increased dowry requests. 8. Retention. In Orissa, the Dhenkenal district has a SC dropout rate of 63 percent and 75 percent for tribals vs. a district figure of 49 percent; Kalahandi shows 59 percent for SC and 60 percent for ST vs. a district total of 55 percent; the predominantly tribal district of Rayagada has an SC rate of 50 percent and ST rate of 58 percent vs. a district level of 44 percent. This data confirms that the disadvantaged groups found it more difficult to remain in school. The reasons are manifold: * There is a lack of parental encouragement; * The child's assistance for seasonal labor or daily chores takes priority over school; * Tribal holidays are not accounted for in the school calendar; * The language gap and cultural gap between student and teacher is discouraging; * Students face difficulty in completing homework assignments due to lack of parental help and kerosene for light; * Parents cannot afford clothes for children to wear to school; and * Migratory families, particularly among the SC population, increase student absenteeism. 9. Quality. The quality of teaching in tribal areas is complicated by a cultural gap between student and teacher, which is often accompanied by a language barrier. This makes learning difficult and discourages the child from further study; * Text books are not available on time; * The curriculum does not reflect tribal activities and traditions; * Teachers are unaware of tribal customs and culture; * Teachers do not speak the tribal language. ST students do not understand the language of instruction;
 - 194 - Annex 15 * Teachers are poorly motivated and often absent, in some cases being used for non-school related tasks; * Teachers are often unqualified and poorly supervised; and * Teachers are not trained in MLL, multigrade teaching or innovative methods. DPEP STRATEGIES TO ADDRESS THE ABOVE-MENTIONED ISSUES 10. To address these issues, DPEP introduced a bottom-up planning process. After training by the DPEP bureau and the TSG, the districts were instructed to hold orientation and planning meetings with local stakeholders: parents, teachers, VEC members, representatives of women's groups, SC/ST populations as well as administrators. These meetings were designed to elicit the views and suggestions of beneficiaries. This feedback was used by the district planning teams to design strategies to improve the educational environment. Table I of this Annex presents a district level description of participation, identified needs and proposed responses. 11. Access. To improve access, districts have proposed a two-prong approach: an increase in the number of educational facilities and an awareness campaign designed to encourage student enrollment. In SC/ST areas, creative solutions to meet the needs of sparsely populated areas will be tried on an experimental basis. This will include residential (ashram) schools, mobile schools in areas of migrant workers, and alternative schools or NFEs in other areas. To combat community lethargy and in some cases resistance, awareness and enrollment campaigns will be organized to focus on the value of education. Some districts have proposed competitions between villages for increased enrollment and retention. 12. To increase enrollment of girls, ECCE programs will provide childcare services, freeing older siblings for school attendance. NFEs, which will allow flexibility in school timings, will be established. A major effort will be made to hire female teachers to provide appropriate role models for girls. Community awareness campaigns will be aided by women's groups and mahila samitis; MTAs and PTAs will be supported; and VECs, once activated, will by law have at least two female members. 13. Retention. Overall, attention will be paid to improving the school infrastructure by repairing dilapidated buildings, constructing toilets, providing drinking water and electricity. VECs will be responsible for assuring that maintenance continues. Continual awareness programs will be conducted to ensure family acceptance and desire for education. VECs will monitor the attendance of teachers and students. For girls, monetary and material incentives will be provided and extended to cover all poor girls. Remedial programs have been proposed to discourage dropout caused by frustration. A concerted effort will be made to hire female teachers and, on an experimental basis, teacher's quarters will be constructed where justified. 14. Quality. School curriculum and teacher competence are the two major components of quality education. DPEP strategies will focus on training. A network of
 - 195 - Annex 15 BRCs, CRCs, and an upgraded DIET will be responsible for conducting training workshops; the SCERT, with the assistance of the NCERT, will develop modules on MLL, multigrade teaching, gender orientation, tribal sensitivity, etc. Training will extend to supervisory staff, ECCE and NFE instructors. Appointment of tribal and gender coordinators at the state and in some cases the district level to assist in training and curriculum issues has been proposed. Tribal language handbooks will be made available in selected districts. 15. Textbook studies will be analyzed to ensure that an adequate number of books can be made available to all students. Committees will review the texts to ensure that gender and tribal bases are eliminated and that they are more attractive and relevant to all groups. Supplemental reading materials will be developed and libraries provided to encourage reading interest and skills. 16. The curriculum will be revised to integrate MLL into all subjects. Innovative teaching schemes will be encouraged, e.g., Joyful Learning. School and teacher contingency funds will be provided to allow for the purchase and development of new teaching aids and other innovative projects. Coordination of activities at the state and district level with tribal institutes, Departments of Tribal Welfare, and Departments of Women's Affairs should result in a more coordinated and relevant curriculum. DPEP I EXPERIENCE: LESSONS LEARNED 17. Changing the structure of education planning, addressing the needs of groups historically removed from the educational mainstream and modifying long held cultural biases requires time, creativity and skill. Taking into account the experience of DPEP I districts can help shorten this process in DPEP It. Sharing workshops or interstate visits should be arranged as soon as possible. 18. The cooperative planning strategy has helped the districts develop skills in the participatory process. The strengthening of the VECs and MTCs in Tamil Nadu has broadened community input into the AWPB. Maharashtra shifted the micro-planning to the block level to ensure community involvement. Evidence in Kamataka shows widespread discussions occurred between community members, NGOs, teachers and experts along with support from major institutions. 19. Next to civil works, social mobilization campaigns comprise a major portion of district budgets. A successful intervention in DPEP I is the Meena campaign in Assam which uses animation films and comic books to stress the importance of education for girls. Many awareness strategies adapted the effective methods developed by the Total Literacy Campaigns. 20. SCERT designed teacher training programs in Haryana have helped the curriculum become more activity and child oriented. Kamataka has developed modules which emphasis gender and tribal needs. To assist in tribal focus, Madhya Pradesh has
 - 196 - Annex 15 deputed staff from the Tribal Welfare Department to the DIET. Assam has developed materials in local languages. Tamil Nadu has relied on residential schools and NFEs. 21. Gender programs have been strengthened by the integration of the Mahila Samahkhya experience, the empowerment of women's groups and the revision of textbooks. In Tamil Nadu, the mother-teacher council is being used to improve girls' participation in the classroom, an escort service to address the security needs of girls has been introduced. Haryana has increased the participation of women on VECs to 50 percent. Madhya Pradesh has extensive experience in providing alternative schools for girls. FUTURE 22. Solutions to improving the level of enrollment, retention and achievement rates in disadvantaged groups are not readily available. Limited national experience and attention to their needs does not give district planning teams much to fall back on. DPEP by focusing attention on these special groups is providing an opportunity for innovation. Yet there is a caution: innovation implies a need for careful study, research and evaluation to determine the demand, feasibility and impact of strategies. Wholesale plans to provide alternate schools, residential schools, teachers' quarters or mobile schools are premature. Districts are, therefore, now concentrating initially on analyzing present programs for their effectiveness and cost benefits. Convergence with ongoing schemes, reliance on relevant resources, and discussions with DPEP I states will cut down on needless experimentation. Once satisfied that a scheme has merit, single units should be tried and evaluated before large scale funds are committed. 23. To facilitate DPEP, districts must develop activity schedules which reflect the need for infrastructure development and micro-planning exercises as a preliminary step. Once the structure is in place innovative schemes can be initiated. Examples of schemes which require further evaluation and workshops to share the results before further expansion are a mobile school in Chamba for migrant workers, teachers quarters in Orissa and an ashram school for tribal students in Dang district in Gujarat. 24. The Department of Education along with TSG must assist the state and district teams in developing the capacity to analyze the information gained from social assessment studies and the participatory meetings to design strategies that form the basis for AWP&B. By fostering an understanding of the utility of the method, greater care will be taken to continue its usage. PRIORITIES 25. In several areas district programs need to be further developed for example, specific programs addressing the needs of SC students, concentration on Tibetan refugees in Himachal, and careful analysis of the needs of the disabled. Moreover, consideration will be given increasingly to village driven issues as ultimately the beneficiaries have the largest stake in the process. This includes the need to address more effectively supply and demand
 - 197 - Annex 15 issues such as location and type of facility to meet the needs of the local population , daily and seasonal timings of school, adaptation of culturally relevant material into the curriculum. Flexibility has been built into the program at the district level to allow community specific changes. As implementation proceeds more specificity will be included in program components, i.e. what type of awareness programs will be instituted, who will they address, how will they be evaluated; how will the curriculum for NFEs (alternative schools) differ, will students move into primary schools after NFE completion; who will ensure that tribal culture is incorporated into the curriculum, how will it be done? 26. Several other possible alternatives could be considered by the communities as part of the DPEP program supporting innovative activity: * providing intensive teacher training to suitable local community members, particularly in tribal areas. This will ensure knowledge of tribal culture and eliminate accommodation issues; * complementing the curriculum with an introduction to handicrafts or vocational skills into the curriculum; and * reviewing school schedule, i.e., 6 hours a day, 6 days a week may be modified based on need. 27. DPEP provides a vehicle for community involvement in education. Building on that mobilization with support, monitoring and evaluation, education for all can become a reality.

 - 202 - Annex 16 INDIA: District Primary Education Project II Supervision Plan 1. Supervision for DPEP II would be fully integrated with supervision for DPEP I (Cr. 2661-IN) and UPBEP (Cr. 2509-IN) and managed from the New Delhi Resident Mission. The IDA supervision of all three credits would be carried out through the joint supervision process that has been developed in the first year of implementation for DPEP. The joint supervision process has been designed to: * review the national and state capacities to effectively manage the implementation of DPEP; spot check the implementation of the project on the ground through field visits and the review of project reports; - provide advice to the DPEP Bureau and the State Implementation Societies with regard to emerging implementation issues; - monitor the implementation of agreed action programs; and * create a framework for collaboration among donors supporting primary education development in India. The supervision of UPBEP so far has been carried out separately by IDA through bi-annual supervision missions with participation by DOE/GOI. 2 So far two joint supervision missions have been carried out (March and September 1994) and a third one is being planned for June 1996. All funding DPEP agencies - European Community, IDA, Unicef, ODA and GOI - have assigned staff and consultants to these supervision missions. The mission leadership is rotating among the agencies: IDA led the first mission, the EC the second, and GOI is expected to lead the third. The missions have functioned as a group of professionals providing advice to the DPEP Bureau rather than as a group of agency representatives. The findings and recommendations of the joint supervision mission have been the basis for IDA internal supervision reporting and IDA has communicated its comments in a follow-up letter to the DPEP Bureau. 3. The effectiveness of the joint DPEP I supervision missions has been considerably enhanced by: internal supervision missions carried out by the DPEP Bureau and the TSG; quarterly reports, supplemented by an annual reports including audited accounts, prepared by the SISs; bi-annual progress reports prepared by the DPEP Bureau; and
 - 203 - Annex 16 training of DPEP staff in procurement and disbursement procedures by specialist staff from NDO. 4. The DPEP Bureau with support of the TSG has supervised the implementation of DPEP in the project districts. Staff in the TSG have led this supervision effort supported by short-term consultants drawn from the pool of national experts from national and state level institutions developed through: * training in supervision procedures and techniques in the Lal Bahadur Shastri National Academy (LBSNAA) in Mussoori; and * participation of national experts in UPBEP and DPEP I supervision missions 5. In addition, staff in the state projects offices have been exposed to a series of training programs related to the implementation of DPEP, including training on procurement and disbursement issues carried out by specialist staff based in the New Delhi office. As a result, several states are taking increasing responsibility for the supervision of the implementation of the project at the district level, the provision of planning support to district level staff and the pre-appraisal of annual work program and budgets prepared by district level staff. 6. The operationalization of a computerized project management information system (PMIS) and education management information system (EMIS), which will provide up-to-date informaticn to project managers in DPEP at the district level and above, is expected to further strengthen the information base of the joint supervision effort. Complemented by a program of research and evaluation that is gradually broadening its scope, the future joint supervision missions will be able to draw on a much richer and much more reliable information base than has been possible in the first twelve months of implementation. 7. The current DPEP supervision strategy needs to be adjusted to take account of the increased scope and complexity of the program as it expands to increase the coverage to 120 districts and 13 states, including Uttar Pradesh. To ensure effective supervision in a program of this magnitude the following steps will be implemented: * explicit delegation of the supervision responsibility to the state offices in all DPEP I states and UP starting April 1997; * a gradual decentralization of supervision responsibility in the second generation DPEP states; * full operationalization of the PMIS in the first generation states by July 1996 and in the second generation states by January 1997; * implementation of the education management information system in all states starting September 1996; and
 - 204 - Annex 16 full operationalization of the research, monitoring and evaluation program, including the monitoring in sample districts, focusing especially on qualitative and process indicators by September 1996 in already participating states and gradual expansion into the second generation states. 8. The supervision of DPEP I, DPEP II and UPBEP will be integrated as follows: * SPOs will institute a process of systematic supervision of the districts. Each district will be visited by state teams at least twice a year. The SPO will submit formnal supervision summary reports in a standard format for review to the DPEP Bureau. A supervision plan will be included in the APB prepared by the state. * The DPEP Bureau will supervise each state once a year through a national supervision mission which will take place at different points in time in. This mission will (i) review the effectiveness of the state supervision; (ii) visit three or four districts in each state for an on-the-ground spot check of implementation progress (double that number in UP and MP); and (iii) review the APB prepared by the districts and the states. A format for a summary supervision report, including a set of performance indicators, will be developed. These supervision summaries would be provided to the donors concerned. The DPEP Bureau will attempt to ensure that each project district will be visited once a year by either ajoint or a national supervision mission. 3 A joint supervision mission will supervise the capacity of the DPEP Bureau to effectively carry out the state level supervision, twice a year for about two weeks. Each mission would visit six states, to allow all states a joint supervision mission visit once a year. * Every year, starting in 1997, a supervision workshop would take place on one or at most two selected topics to bring together all states. In this workshops states would report on their experience with a specific components of the DPEP program (e.g., micro planning, NFE, ECCE, civil works , teacher training, multigrade teaching, etc.). The topics will be selected by the DPEP Bureau in consultation with the donors. The workshop would typically last one week and take place outside Delhi in one of the states that has some notable achievements. An external speaker could be invited to deliver a keynote address on the selected topic. * At this workshop the DPEP Bureau would present an overview of project achievements, while each state would present its annual report and an overview of its achievements in an exhibition space.
